image.altText: Snowtown accomplice Mark Haydon in a cap and jumper.

props.synopsis: Mark Ray Haydon, who was an accessory to Australia's worst serial killings, left the Adelaide pre-release centre on Thursday where he has been living on parole, the head of the Parole Board says.

title.children: Snowtown accomplice released into the community under strict supervision

image.altText: Karoline Dawe and Kylie Ward wearing nice evening dresses outside a gala event.

props.synopsis: Senior executives at Australia's peak body for nurses have been sacked after an investigation found alleged "financial irregularities".

title.children: Head of nursing body sacked following financial investigation

image.altText: A person removing tattoos from a man's arm, both wearing protective glasses and sitting

props.synopsis: Pen ink, household paint, even watered-down ash — laser tattoo removalist Phil Pagdin has seen it all. He's among those in the industry concerned about the safety of home tattoo kits available to buy online.

title.children: Household paint, pen ink, and watered-down ash used in DIY tattoos prompt warnings over home kits

image.altText: Man in hospital receiving care

props.synopsis: International student Devarshi Deka had high hopes when he came to Australia. But an alleged assault has left him unable to walk, and his family is appealing for support so returning to India isn't his only option.

title.children: Dev came to Australia as a university student. He'll leave a paraplegic with no support

image.altText: Kieren appears close to tears, dressed in a black top and burgundy cardigan as she sits inside.

props.synopsis: A mother says a man armed with a knife told her to "just stop crying" as he forced her to drive and buy laptops in Melbourne's south-east while her six-month-old daughter sat in the back seat.

title.children: Melbourne mother recalls 'begging' armed abductor to leave her and daughter alone

image.altText: A composite image of an older man and an older woman smiling.

props.synopsis: A jury hears longstanding friends of camper Russell Hill raised the alarm after he failed to join a nightly radio call. Mr Hill and his lover Carol Clay were allegedly murdered by Greg Lynn while on a camping trip in Victoria's High Country in 2020.

title.children: 'Those were the last words he spoke to me': Friends of killed camper Russell Hill give evidence in murder trial

image.altText: Vandals cut down 135-year-old statue of former Tasmanian premier William Crowther

props.synopsis: A statue of divisive colonial-era figure William Crowther has stood in central Hobart since 1889, that was until one night this week when it was toppled. Video has surfaced showing people carrying out the act.

title.children: Video of vandal toppling statue of controversial premier posted online as police investigate

image.altText: Split image of colourful lights in the sky and a singer standing on a platform with arms open

props.synopsis: Are you across this week's news headlines? Put yourself to the test.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: Stunning auroras, federal budget handed down, and a history-making Eurovision

image.altText: Peter Dutton budget reply

props.synopsis: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has used his budget reply speech to advocate a reduction to migration numbers.

title.children: Dutton calls to slash permanent migration and international student numbers

image.altText: Gabrielle Morrissey

props.synopsis: Domestic, family and sexual violence organisations are warning they will need to start winding back services because the federal government hasn’t invested enough in the sector in its latest budget.

title.children: 'Trickery and deception': Frontline domestic violence services say federal budget a let-down

image.altText: A silhouette photograph of two teenagers, back to back in chairs, on their smartphones

props.synopsis: Deciding when and how children should access social media is a universal challenge for parents and there's not always a one-size-fits-all solution — even when it comes to kids in the same family.

title.children: 'Our two children's needs are entirely different': Parents' thoughts on banning social media for children

image.altText: a composite image of Justin Stein who is accused of murdering nine-year-old Charlise Mutten in 2022

props.synopsis: A NSW Supreme Court jury is played the second police interview with Justin Stein that records a key difference from his first.

title.children: Alleged killer of 9yo girl changed story hours after first police interview, court told

image.altText: A man smiling in parliament

props.synopsis: Every budget week, a chorus of voices urges the opposition leader to "put some meat on the bones" of his alternative policy vision for the nation. This year is no different, writes Annabel Crabb.

title.children: Dutton's reply was everything we should expect: a calculated, ideological butchery of the most vulnerable budget bits

image.altText: Two middle aged women look at the camera and smile as they pose for a selfie.

props.synopsis: The first of the extra 1,000 security personnel France is sending to New Caledonia have started to arrive amid riots that have killed five people and injured hundreds more, with the French government saying a state of emergency has started to calm things in the Pacific territory.

title.children: Australians trapped in New Caledonia barricaded in accommodation for five days as violence spreads

image.altText: A glass of red wine on a  wooden veranda rail, overlooking a vineyard.

props.synopsis: Wine industry representatives say they will fight for financial assistance after this week's federal budget left them disappointed.

title.children: Wine industry warns regional communities at risk of collapse without aid for sector

image.altText: A vintage rusted truck lies on it's side

props.synopsis: The expansive red dirt plains of north-west Queensland are littered with the skeletons of hundreds of car bodies, but residents may have found a solution.

title.children: Rusted, burnt-out cars plaguing outback landscape that 'just don't belong here'

image.altText: A pile of discarded bottles and other rubbish in sand dunes

props.synopsis: A wildlife photographer says the amount of rubbish left in the dunes of South Australia's Goolwa Beach grows worse each year as the council and police consider how to better control access.

title.children: Permits to access famous beach on the cards as piles of litter show 'some people just don't care'

props.synopsis: Over the past decade in Broken Hill, the city's Sufi community has become more prominent, with the establishment of the locally revered Sufi Bakery, as well as an Islamic study centre and a Sufi bookshop.

title.children: With heart, soul, books and bread, the Sufi community calls this outback city home

image.altText: Head shot of Iranian man looking at the camera but body facing to the right with a desert background.

props.synopsis: Rapper Toomaj Salehi is facing the death penalty for using his music to draw attention to the actions of the Iranian government. Now artists and activists from around the world are trying to save him.

title.children: Rapper Toomaj Salehi's courage to speak out has won him fans all over the world. Now he's facing the death penalty

image.altText: A man in a navy blue suit wearing a blue tie.

props.synopsis: This week's assassination attempt on Slovakia's PM Robert Fico has shone a light on deep political divisions in the country, but there could also be a lesson for several other world leaders in the attack.

title.children: Why, to some, the shooting of Slovakia’s love-or-loathe PM came as no surprise

image.altText: A man sitting on the ground with handcuffs on, with his back to the camera, surrounded by other men.

props.synopsis: Slovakia's Prime Minister Robert Fico is in a "very serious" but stable condition, a hospital official says, after he was shot five times, as a man is charged with attempted murder over Wednesday's attack.

title.children: Slovakian PM Fico stable after surgery but condition 'very serious', man charged with attempted murder

image.altText: A composite image of headshots of Vivek Ramaswamy, Donald Trump and Doug Burgum

props.synopsis: Donald Trump has come face to face with several enemies in court, including the prosecution's star witness, whose scathing evidence is continuing. But this week, there were some friendlier faces in the courtroom too.

title.children: The Apprentice, VP edition: Veep try-outs at the Trump trial as a sworn enemy unloads

image.altText: A composite image of Omar bin Omran. One photo shows him as a teenager. The other when he was found as an adult.

props.synopsis: An Algerian man who went missing 26 years ago has been found in his neighbour's cellar, just 200 metres away from where he grew up, the country's justice ministry says.

title.children: 'Heinous': Algerian man missing for 26 years found in neighbour's cellar

image.altText: A close up of a girl's hands looking on a phone.

props.synopsis: The EU has outlined their main concerns as the algorithms stimulating behavioural addictions in children creating the "rabbit-hole effect", and Meta's age assurance and verification methods.

title.children: The EU says Instagram and Facebook may be too addictive for children in probe, here's what we know

image.altText: A man wearing a blue jacket skis through snow pulling a sled.

props.synopsis: The team is trekking 560 kilometres to the summit of the Greenland ice cap after NASA reported it had shrunk a fifth more than previously thought.

title.children: Australian explorer pulling 70kg sled for 20km a day in freezing conditions through Greenland in research mission

image.altText: A man wearing a black polo top smiles.

props.synopsis: Flinders University opens planning and surveying courses to help fill a national shortage of professionals needed to ease the housing crisis.

title.children: SA university opens planning, surveying degrees amid nation-wide shortage

image.altText: A view of the Whyalla steelworks taken at sunset

props.synopsis: South Australia's energy minister has travelled to Italy to "eyeball" the firm tasked with developing a $500 million furnace for the Whyalla steelworks, as the owners of the plant reveal the project is at least a year behind schedule.

title.children: Further delays forecast as owners say Whyalla steelworks project at least a year behind schedule

image.altText: A juvenile skate on the sea floor.

props.synopsis: Scientists last year raised the alarm — twice — about the fate of Tasmania's endangered Maugean skate after its population was found to have declined by 47 per cent. But while the salmon industry maintains that all's well, it has also asked for a shift in goal posts to redefine a 'healthy' harbour to a 'viable' one.

title.children: Salmon farms are this species' main extinction threat. But have the farms changed – or just kept going?

image.altText: Peter Dutton shakes hands with colleagues in the House of Representatives.

props.synopsis: In his budget reply, Peter Dutton tapped into the electorally emotive issues of housing and immigration. It was a logical path to take.

title.children: Dutton takes aim at the budget's 'magic pudding' spending but the opposition now faces a tax dilemma

image.altText: People walk past a stock market graph in a window.

props.synopsis: The ASX200 is down on Friday after Wall Street lost value overnight.

title.children: ASX down on Friday, Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin pledge 'new era' of strategic cooperation

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: RBA and government 'running a fine line with scissors', says Westpac chief economist
Why are Bendigo Bank shares higher?
ASX dragged lower by losses in healthcare, real estate

image.altText: Jamie Chapman dives over the line

props.synopsis: The opener to the first three-game Women's State of Origin starts with a bang thanks to Jaime Chapman and finishes poetically with Caitlan Johnston sealing NSW's victory. Here are five quick hits from Game I at Lang Park.

title.children: Five quick hits — Caitlan claps back, Chappy's happy and Manzelmann mucks it up

image.altText: Billie Eilish hit me hard and soft header

props.synopsis: Somewhere along the way, global superstar Billie Eilish fell out of love with making music. Here's why making her third blockbuster album brought the passion back.

title.children: How going to the gym and DJ'ing shaped Billie Eilish's suprising third album

image.altText: A man wearing dark glasses leans over and smells a handful of grain.

props.synopsis: Breweries are increasingly turning to unusual and sustainable products and production methods to stand out in a competitive market.

title.children: Boutique brewer launches beer made with camel dung

image.altText: Mandarins loose on a kitchen counter next to mandarins packed in a Coles-branded brown recyclable paper bag with a net window.

props.synopsis: Small and big retailers alike are looking to adopt new recyclable packaging for mandarins, saying it would avoid the use of 11,700 kilograms of plastic in one year.

title.children: Paper bags make a comeback for fruit as retailers swap out plastic net bags to reduce waste

image.altText: AFL player Charlie Cameron, holding the yellow football, with a defender behind him, as they both come to a stop

props.synopsis: Two draws this AFL season have led to some suggesting the league needs extra time. But rather than fuel the need for a winner, why not celebrate the draw with a song?

title.children: As the argument for extra time grows, maybe the AFL should consider celebrating the awkward draw
